reviewText:
Product received for free

This game is an old school MMORPG which was released back in 2004, and got green lit on steam and released on this platform in 2016. The graphics have been similar since the game's first launch, there haven't been any major changes. If I were to talk about pros and cons of the game:

Pros:
Amazing pvp system, pulls you right into it.
Unique merchanting system
Unique upgrade system
Old school MMO atmosphere
Active communityCons:
The game is very grindy, it's super difficult to reach level cap without having a paid subscription
There are some broken quests but they aren't game breaking
Lack of a proper anti-cheat software causing cheaters to take advantage of it very easily
In game store to buy goods to benefit one's character during PvP (pay to win element). The store is called Power Up Store (PUS) and includes monthly subscriptions, potions and scrolls that increase your health, armor, attack and stats.
Websites that buy and sell in-game money illegally
Monthly subscription plans are more expensive than any other modern MMO on the market, convenient ones starting from $30/mo going up to $40/mo
Lack of communication between the publisher and the developers, causing confusions and delays on some occasions
So in my opinion, the cons weigh out the pros and I ended up quitting the game after playing it for more than 3 months and spending over 800 hours and a ton of money. If you still want to play, it's completely up to you. I'm not saying that you won't enjoy the game, but the facts are out there.

Cheers to whoever takes their time to read this

Game itself is good to be honest. It's a very grind-heavy game where you have to spend time to farm up xp and items. The end goal is to be effective in PvP which is heavily reliant on gear and skill.
Events are fun, amazing PvP, and pretty good role play.
The cons of this game are endless however. I honestly believe that if this game were run by a better gaming company such as Blizzard or Riot, it would be one of the top MMORPGs.
The company who runs the game (NTTGame) is beyond corrupt. The game is literally pay-to-win and it is nearly impossible to compete with other players if you don't pay at least 40-50$ to start the game off.
Furthermore the support system is complete garbage. There are tons of bugs and god forbid you get affected by one of them (items missing, character bug, etc.), you will have to send a support ticket in, which may very well never get answered. Mines been up for 21 days now, and I know others who have been waiting 30-40 days.
Also the quests aren't very entertaining, the game was translated from Turkish to English so most of the dialect with NPCs is incomprehensible, and there is a pretty loose anti-cheat policy.
The game allows cheaters to play to increase the player count as well as to force them to purchase things via the Power Up Store (real money) and then slaps them on the wrist so they can continue reaping money off of them.
The game has an incredibly small staff, the support team is inefficient and the system for handling tickets is very poorly designed, and new bugs are always introduced every patch (developers are mediocre at best).
When you think of good games, the software cycle for them is usually well defined and everything is done by procedure. This game appears to be hacked together and each patch introduces new problems due to this (as any programmer would know...hacking for large scale projects is never the route to go).
I hope to god this game gets new management or some changes are made to the staff...because this game honestly has potential in the right hands.

reviewText:
I'm not saying I had tears in my eyes when I heard the menu music, but I'm not saying I didn't, either.

I played KO very early in its lifespan, and even back then the game was very p2win, very hardcore, very grindy. After grinding to 60 on my healer over months, I got invited to join the top guild on my Malaysian server (where I PvPed from Germany on a dial-up connection). My Malaysian guild master would spend his weekly income on cash-shop boosters for PvP and would hook the rest of us up too, even if it meant he couldn't afford food.

It felt great being part of a good guild, swaggering about in our fancy cloaks with our logo on it, I had an absolute blast despite 90% of the playerbase consisting of 12 year old Turks in internet cafes, and 10% being 12 yeard old Malaysians in internet cafes.

PvP was fun and never got old to me, due to animation-cancelling (you could combo in a very efficient way) and sliding (allowing you to stay moving as you attack). I don't know if I would have enjoyed the game nearly as much or even stuck with it as long as I did without those.

The game was absolutely plagued by bugs and poor programming (no leashing, ridiculous threat mechanics, rampant botting and straight-up hacks) and more than once have I witnessed guildmates' accounts being stolen (internet cafes, remember?).

I don't know if this changed since MYKO, but you used to lose 5%(?) XP every time you died (several hours worth of grind beyond level 60), so my friends' compromised characters would often be seen running into mobs face first, in an attempt to de-level the character. Yes, you could level down if you lost XP while below 5% XP into the next level.

It was an awesome, terrible game, and I will always think of it lovingly, with good memories- but I have no idea why anyone would subject themselves to this now...why is this even on Steam?!

I'm gonna faff around in it and maybe even try to level, but I can not honestly recommend anyone play this. Under modern standards, this game is a piece of crap (and the monetization is almost criminal). Just go play Blade & Soul.

reviewText:
[UPDATED: 3/2/2016]

My review WAS a thumbs up. In fact, the publisher (NTTGame) held a contest: “Whoever posts a positive review may be selected to win a prize.” Guess what? I won. At the time, the game was brand new to Steam, and I had high hopes that NTTGame wouldn’t purposely ‘screw over’ their customers.

I’ve played Knight Online since I was 14. I’m 26 now. Knight Online has many different versions based on region: MYKO, KRKO, JAPKO, TWKO, USKO, EUKO (a western-friendly name for TRKO), and now this SteamKO. My excitement about the Steam launch was my misjudgment that the publishers would re-invent how Knight Online is marketed, and how their cash shop was offered. KO already had a bad reputation as a P2P/P2W while labeling themselves as free (even using the trademark “Free2Play”). However, since the launch on Steam, it went from bad, to worse.

THE GAME ITSELF IS NOT BAD. The company that runs the game appears to drive it into the ground. We regulars can’t figure out why. All they need to really do is boost their communication and TAKE our suggestions. KO players are very patient, but not when they are utterly ignored.

So why should YOU avoid this game?
While I will always believe you should at least give the game a shot, I DON’T want you to spend a dime to do it. Here’s why:

Server connectivity can be extremely laggy at times, and you will certainly be disconnected a few times in a day. Sometimes it’s routine maintenance, but other times it’s completely random. Their staff does little to keep the community informed, so you’re left thinking “is it my connection?” Not to mention, if you aren’t premium – you won’t stay logged in regardless.

Servers have a population cap of 3,000. It used to be a lot more than that, as the maps are huge and designed for about 8,000 people per server, but the game doesn’t fair that well, so they reduce the cap and you are forced to be on a waiting list during peak hours. The waiting list can be up to an hour long, and if you wait too long, you will get an automatic DC. This is with or without premium. Oh yes, even premium members will be waiting.

The prices in SteamKO are outrageous. You are forced to buy almost double the amount, even if you only want a few small things. It’s all or nothing, basically. This was a horrible idea for a new Steam launch. Their marketing manager should be fired. Not to mention, prices have been increased dramatically for certain premium items, WITHOUT NOTICE.

There’s different monthly premium options. For example, EXP Premium lets you level up faster, WAR Premium lets you rank higher during PVP. They’ve enabled you to buy both, at the same time, but they aren’t stackable. They will run out in 30 days, regardless if you use it or not, as if you were actually just leasing premium from them. This wouldn’t be a huge problem, if they didn’t have a lot of issues that happen within those 30 days, preventing you from playing/enjoying the game.

Hackers. Hackers are everywhere, it makes your eyes bleed. They either only have 1-2 GM’s, or the multiple GM’s online just don’t like to do their job in-game as much. Regardless of the reason, there’s no excuse for the excessive hackers. There have been SO MANY positive suggestions from the community regarding how to deal with hackers, but the staff appears to ignore the problem as if it doesn’t exist. This is literally what killed the older KO games, and it seems to be doing a number on SteamKO as well. You want to PVP? Too bad, you get a party full of hackers attacking you instead. You want to kill a boss? Sorry, hackers already killed it. You want to Exp? Too bad, all the spots are taken by hackers. The freaking game already has an “auto attack” option for paying players (P2W again), yet people still would rather buy actual hacks to do it.

Pay to PLAY: Oh yes, consider this game “free to try” but “pay to enjoy.” You can certainly log in for free and play for a while. But consider that no clan will ever recruit you because you aren’t competitive, you NEED premium items to PVP (or you will always die), you NEED premium items to reach the level cap, you will NEED premium to have a stable-enough connection to merchant. You NEED premium if you want to log into the first server and have a chance to bypass the waiting list. Don’t come here if you think you can stay without paying, you will be gravely disappointed.

Pay to WIN: You could play the game – without paying – for a whole year. Once a premium member enters the picture, within a month he has surpassed you. The more money you throw at the company, the more intense your character becomes. It’s far from cosmetics. This has always been the case, and this will never change. Some people prefer it that way, because they’re fine throwing away half their paycheck every month. Personally, I spend as much as I would on eating a cheeseburger.

Extreme community censorship. The forum moderators like to lock as many negative posts they can find. This is typical of the old community, but it carried over to the Steam forum as well. It’s highly censored, and anyone who disagrees with moderators is promptly banned with their post deleted. There have been complaints against the moderators, but in reality it has always been the case.

The admins have limited 1 computer per IP address. Supposedly they’ve done this to combat the hordes of hackers who are using the same ISP, but given the pattern of late, it appears they are actually doing this to force the lower 15% of their player base who live in dorms, play in cafes, or have a family playing together, to buy premium. The IP restriction doesn’t apply if you have premium. I draw this theory due to the fact that these hackers are indeed… hackers, and they just use masked ISPs/proxies to bypass the silly IP restriction. So in reality, all of the legal players are being punished. There has been no slowing down of the hacking trend.

The most irritating part is the lack of communication. The community has been *demanding* certain standard features that have been locked for no apparent reason (DCZ/RLB, for example). There has been no explanation on why certain things have been locked, or when they will be open, or when certain bugs will be fixed, or what they have planned for upcoming events. Not a peep.

RECENTLY, they've decided to hold an event that literally says Whoever spends more money will win a prize" -- is this not the very definition of Pay-To-Win?

Knight Online is a old game which is at least 10 years old. It still retain the old graphics and control from back then. It was one of the most popular MMO title at that time.

In the first 25 minutes after launch:
>the server goes down twice

Classic KO.

EDIT: In all seriousness...
To the newcomers/foreigners/returning-after-many-years: Think twice. This is a 11 year old game with a dedicated userbase. It isn't free to play, it's actually pay to win. It is traditionally babashopping central. Most of the time you won't even be able to connect without buying a premium. The only good thing about the game is the PvP mechanic which requires you to heavily invest your time (grind towards level ~80) and money to even begin enjoying it. Also the community is 90% Turkish and yes, the launch was terrible.
Despite all this if you decide to take the plunge it offers solid and satisfying PvP action, if you can actually get there.

To the USKO players/recent returnees: Pretty much the same. Level cap is 80 for now. Krowaz, Dragon Boxes etc. are disabled for now, along with Ardream and RLB. You can get more info at the community hub. PUS and the cash system is a mess right now but it will get sorted out eventually. Servers are still a little wobbly but that is to be expected since they are filled to the brim. Queue is around 1000 players for each server right now (6 a.m on a weekday). There are definitely more foreigners.
